maml:description.maml:para: Adds an collection element to an IIS configuration collection.
The Add-WebConfiguration cmdlet adds a collection element to an existing IIS configuration collection.
The value to add to the configuration collection. This can be a single value or a value/key combination in a hash table.
The element in the collection location at which the value is to be inserted.
The index at which the value is to be inserted.
The name at which the value is to be inserted.
Overrides existing element settings.
The location to which the configuration is written.
A configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration section or a configuration element that contains a collection.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The value to add to the configuration collection. This can be a single value or a value/key combination in a hash table.
The element in the collection location at which the value is to be inserted.
The index at which the value is to be inserted.
The name at which the value is to be inserted.
Overrides existing element settings.
The location to which the configuration is written.
A configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration section or a configuration element that contains a collection.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Adding a new Default Document --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds a new Default Document to the Default Document collection of the Default Web Site. By using "-atIndex 0" the new Default Document is inserted at the top of the list.

maml:description.maml:para: Locks an IIS configuration section or element
Locks an IIS configuration section, element, or attribute.
Specifies the type of configuration lock to add.
Forces the configuration lock.
Passes an object representing the configuration lock to the pipeline
The location at which the configuration lock is to be inserted.
An XPath filter expression.

Specifies the configuration path to the site on which to set the lock. The path can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Specifies the type of configuration lock to add.
Forces the configuration lock.
Passes an object representing the configuration lock to the pipeline
The location at which the configuration lock is to be inserted.
An XPath filter expression.

Specifies the configuration path to the site on which to set the lock. The path can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Adding and removing configuration locks --------------
command:example.dev:code: Add-WebConfigurationLock -Type general -Filter //asp Remove-WebConfigurationLock -Filter //asp Add-WebConfigurationLock -Type inclusive -Filter //asp/@lcid Remove-WebConfigurationLock -Filter //asp/@lcid Add-WebConfigurationLock -Type exclusive -Filter //asp/@lcid

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example demonstrates how to add and remove inclusive and exclusive locks using a filter.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a property to an IIS configuration section.
Adds a property to an IIS configuration section. Globbing is supported.
The name of the IIS configuration property to add.
The type of property to add.
The value of the configuration property to add.
The element at which the value is to be inserted.
The index at which the property is to be inserted.
The property name at which the property is to be inserted.
Forces the property to be written. If a lock exists, the property is written at a level in the configuration above the lock.

Location of the configuration property setting. Location tags are usually used for configuration settings that need to be more granular than per application or per virtual directory. Settings for particular files or directory are an example. Location tags are also used is if a particular section is locked. If so the configuration system has to use location tags in one of the parent configuration files.
Specifies the IIS configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration element.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The name of the IIS configuration property to add.
The type of property to add.
The value of the configuration property to add.
The element at which the value is to be inserted.
The index at which the property is to be inserted.
The property name at which the property is to be inserted.
Forces the property to be written. If a lock exists, the property is written at a level in the configuration above the lock.

Location of the configuration property setting. Location tags are usually used for configuration settings that need to be more granular than per application or per virtual directory. Settings for particular files or directory are an example. Location tags are also used is if a particular section is locked. If so the configuration system has to use location tags in one of the parent configuration files.
Specifies the IIS configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration element.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Adding a Default Document --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a new Default Document named "new-index.html" to the top of the list of existing documents.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a backup of an IIS configuration.
Creates a backup of an IIS configuration. A folder named with the value of the Name parameter is created for the backup in the $env:windir\System32\inetsrv\backup folder.

The name of the folder created to store the backup files. A folder with the name specified is created in the $env:windir\system32\inetsrv\backup folder. If a backup with the name specified already exists an error is returned.

The name of the folder created to store the backup files. A folder with the name specified is created in the $env:windir\system32\inetsrv\backup folder. If a backup with the name specified already exists an error is returned.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Backing up an IIS configuration --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Demonstrates how to create a backup of your IIS configuration in a folder named "MyIISBackup".
Name Creation Date ---- ------------- MyIISBackup 2/20/2009 12:00:00 AM

maml:description.maml:para: Instructs the IIS configuration system to delay the commitment of changes.
Instructs the IIS configuration system to delay the commitment of changes. The commitment of changes is delayed remains until the End-WebCommitDelay cmdlet is executed.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Delaying the commit of changes --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Delays the modification of IIS configuration settings until the End-WebCommitDelay cmdlet is executed.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes configuration settings from the configuration location specified.
Removes configuration settings from the configuration location specified.
Forces the specified configuration to be cleared.

The location of the configuration setting to clear. Location tags are usually used for configuration settings that need to be more granular than per application or per virtual directory. Settings for particular files or a specific directory are an example. Location tags are also used if a particular section is locked. If this case, the configuration system has to use location tags in a parent configuration file.
Specifies the IIS configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration element.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Forces the specified configuration to be cleared.

The location of the configuration setting to clear. Location tags are usually used for configuration settings that need to be more granular than per application or per virtual directory. Settings for particular files or a specific directory are an example. Location tags are also used if a particular section is locked. If this case, the configuration system has to use location tags in a parent configuration file.
Specifies the IIS configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration element.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Removing ASP configuration on the root node --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the <asp> section from the root node.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 2: Remove a configuration property from the root node --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example removes the lcid property from the IIS configuration root node.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 3: Removing configuration from the site node --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Remove the <asp> section from the IIS configuration node for the Default Web Site.

maml:description.maml:para: Clears Request Tracing configuration from the specified Web site.
Clears Request Tracing settings from the specified Web site. It also disables Request Tracing for the site.
The name of the site from which Request Trace settings are cleared.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The name of the site from which Request Trace settings are cleared.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Removing Request Tracing from the Default Web Site --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Demonstrates how to remove Request Tracing from the Default Web Site.

maml:description.maml:para: Converts an IIS virtual directory to an IIS Web application.
Converts an IIS virtual directory to an IIS Web application.
The application pool in which the application is to run.
Forces the conversion without prompting for user confirmation.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The application pool in which the application is to run.
Forces the conversion without prompting for user confirmation.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Convert a Virtual Directory to a Web Application --------------
command:example.dev:code: md $env:systemdrive\inetpub\Contoso New-WebVirtualDirectory -Site "Default Web Site" -Name ContosoVDir -physicalPath $env:systemdrive\inetpub\Contoso ConvertTo-WebApplication "IIS:\Sites\Default Web Site\ContosoVDir"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates a physical directory named "Contoso". It then creates a virtual directory in IIS using that physical directory. It then converts the Virtual Directory to a Web application.

Disables an IIS module.
The name of the module to disable.
The location in which to write the configuration.

Disables Request Tracing but does not remove Request Tracing settings.

Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

maml:description.maml:para: Enables an IIS module.
Enables an IIS module.
The name of the module to enable.
Specifies the managed type of the module.
Specifies a precondition for the module.
Forces the module to be enabled.
The location in which the module is enabled.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Forces the module to be enabled.
The location in which the module is enabled.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
The name of the module to enable.
Specifies the managed type of the module.
Specifies a precondition for the module.
Forces the module to be enabled.
The location in which the module is enabled.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').

maml:description.maml:para: Enables the Request Tracing feature.
This command enables the Request Tracing feature and automatically configures a site rule that traces responses that have a status between 400 and 600.
The name of the site for which tracing is enabled.
The directory in which to store Request Tracing log files.
The maximum number of log files to store.
The maximum file size of a single Request Tracing log file.
Specifies an action taken when a Request Tracing log file is generated.
Status codes for which a default Request Tracing rule should be configured. The default is 500.
The name of the site for which tracing is enabled.
The directory in which to store Request Tracing log files.
The maximum number of log files to store.
The maximum file size of a single Request Tracing log file.
Specifies an action taken when a Request Tracing log file is generated.
Status codes for which a default Request Tracing rule should be configured. The default is 500.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Enabling Request Tracing for the "Default Web Site" --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Enables Request Tracing for the Default Web Site, which also automatically creates a rule that traces 500 errors.

maml:description.maml:para: Instructs the IIS configuration system to resume the commitment of changes.

Instructs the configuration system to end the delay of commitment changes started with the Begin-WebCommitDelay cmdlet. You can choose to either commit or discard the configuration changes made using the Commit parameter.
Commit flag that tells the IIS configuration system to commit changes when the flag is set to $true, or to discard changes when set to $false.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Commit flag that tells the IIS configuration system to commit changes when the flag is set to $true, or to discard changes when set to $false.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Commit configuration changes --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Commits the configuration changes made since the Begin-WebCommitDelay cmdlet was executed.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 2: Discard configuration changes --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Discards the configuration changes made since the Begin-WebCommitDelay cmdlet was executed.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the Application Domains in which the specified IIS worker process is running.

The input object from which parameter data is received.
The application pool for which the AppDomains is returned.
The ID of the worker process for which the AppDomain is returned.
The input object from which parameter data is received.
The application pool for which the AppDomains is returned.
The ID of the worker process for which the AppDomain is returned.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Get the AppDomain of a running Worker Process --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: The example gets the AppDomains loaded in the specified Worker Process. The process ID can be retrieved by looking at the WorkerProcesses node below the AppPools node, e.g. get-ChildItem IIS:\AppPools\DefaultAppPool\WorkerProcesses

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the bindings on the specified IIS site.

The name of the site for which binding information is returned.

The port for which the binding is configured.
The IP address for which the the binding is configured.
The host name for which the binding is configured.

The host name for which the binding is configured.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the file system path of the web.config file.

The IIS module namespace path to site containing the web.config file to get.
The IIS module namespace path to site containing the web.config file to get.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example demonstrates how to use Notepad to open the web.config file for the Default Web Site.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets an IIS configuration element at the specified path.
Gets the IIS configuration element at the specified location.
Returns all elements contained in the specified location and subsequent hierarchy.
Returns configuration metadata such as encryption or locking settings.

Location of the configuration setting. Location tags are usually used for configuration settings that need to be more granular than per application or per virtual directory. Settings for particular files or directory are an example.
Specifies the configuration path for which the configuration element(s) should be returned.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Returns all elements contained in the specified location and subsequent hierarchy.
Returns configuration metadata such as encryption or locking settings.

Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').

maml:description.maml:para: Gets an IIS configuration property at the specified path.
Get-WebConfigurationProperty is very similar to Get-Configuration. Get-WebConfigurationProperty supports globbing (wildcards) however.
The name of the property to get.
Returns the properties of nodes contained within the specified node hierarchy when -Recurse is specified.

The location of the configuration setting. Location tags are usually used for configuration settings that need to be more granular than per application or per virtual directory. Settings for particular files or directory are an example.
Specifies the IIS configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration element.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').

Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').

maml:description.maml:para: Gets an IIS virtual directory.

The name of the site for which a list of virtual directories is returned.
The name of a Web application with which virtual directories are associated.
The name of a virtual directory to return.
The name of the site for which a list of virtual directories is returned.
The name of a Web application with which virtual directories are associated.
The name of a virtual directory to return.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Getting a virtual directory --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This cmdlet returns the list of virtual directories on the specified site.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new IIS Web Application.
Creates a new IIS Web Application.
The name of the site on which the application is created.
The name of the web application to create.
The physical path to the Web application files.
The name of the application pool in which the new Web application executes.
Forces the creation of the application without prompting for user confirmation.
The name of the site on which the application is created.
The name of the web application to create.
The physical path to the Web application files.
The name of the application pool in which the new Web application executes.
Forces the creation of the application without prompting for user confirmation.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Creating a new web application --------------
command:example.dev:code: New-WebApplication -Name testApp -Site 'Default Web Site' -PhysicalPath c:\test -ApplicationPool DefaultAppPool

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates a new web application named "testApp" on the Default Web Site.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new IIS application pool.

The name of the IIS application pool to create.
Forces the operation without prompting
The name of the IIS application pool to create.
Forces the operation without prompting

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Create new IIS Application Pool --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates a new IIS application pool named "NewAppPool".

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a new Web site binding to an existing Web site.
Adds a new Web site binding to an existing Web site.
The name of the Web site on which the new binding is created.
The protocol to be used for the Web binding (usually http, https or ftp).
The port to be used for the binding.
The IP address of the new web binding.
The host header of the new Web binding.
Forces the creation of the binding.
The name of the Web site on which the new binding is created.
The protocol to be used for the Web binding (usually http, https or ftp).
The port to be used for the binding.
The IP address of the new web binding.
The host header of the new Web binding.
Forces the creation of the binding.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new binding on the Default Web Site.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new FTP7 Site
Creates a new FTP site. FTP7 or later is required.
The name of the new FTP site.
The ID of the new FTP site.
The port number of the new FTP site.
The IP Address of the new FTP site.
The host header of the new FTP site.
The physical path to the new FTP site. The folder specified must already exist.
Forces the new FTP site to be created.
The name of the new FTP site.
The ID of the new FTP site.
The port number of the new FTP site.
The IP Address of the new FTP site.
The host header of the new FTP site.
The physical path to the new FTP site. The folder specified must already exist.
Forces the new FTP site to be created.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Adding a new FTP binding --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new FTP site named "testFtpSite" (works with FTP7 only).

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new IIS Web site.
Creates a new IIS Web site.

The ID to use for the new site.
The port to use for the new site.
The IP address of the new site.
The host header to use for the new site.
The physical path to use for the new site. The folder specified must already exist.
The application pool in which the new site executes.
Including the -Ssl parameter enables HTTPS binding on the site.
Forces the new site to be created.

The IP address of the new site.
The host header to use for the new site.
The physical path to use for the new site. The folder specified must already exist.

Including the -Ssl parameter enables HTTPS binding on the site.
Forces the new site to be created.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Creating a Virtual Directory --------------

maml:description.maml:para: Removes an IIS Web Application.
Removes an IIS Web Application.
The name of the site from which the application is to be removed.
The name of the application to be removed from the site.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The name of the site from which the application is to be removed.
The name of the application to be removed from the site.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Adding a web application and removing it --------------
command:example.dev:code: New-WebApplication -Name TestApp -Site "Default Web Site" -PhysicalPath "$env:systemdrive\inetpub\TestApp" "Sleep for 5 seconds before Web App is removed"; Sleep 5 Remove-WebApplication -Name TestApp -Site "Default Web Site"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example demonstrates creating a Web application named "TestApp" on the default Web site. The application is then removed after 5 seconds.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes an IIS application pool.
Removes an IIS application pool.
The name of the application pool to be removed.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The name of the application pool to be removed.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Removing an Application Pool --------------
command:example.dev:code: New-WebAppPool MyNewAppPool "Sleep for 5 seconds before AppPool gets removed"; Sleep 5 Remove-WebAppPool MyNewAppPool

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example demonstrates creating a new application pool and then removing it after waiting 5 seconds.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a binding from an IIS Web site.
Removes a binding from an IIS Web site.
The protocol of the binding to remove.
The name of the site from which the binding is removed.
The IP address of the site from which the binding is removed. "*" can be used to specify all IP addresses.
The port of the binding to remove.
The host header of the site binding to remove.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The protocol of the binding to remove.
The name of the site from which the binding is removed.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The protocol of the binding to remove.
The name of the site from which the binding is removed.
A BindingInformation object.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The protocol of the binding to remove.
The name of the site from which the binding is removed.
The IP address of the site from which the binding is removed. "*" can be used to specify all IP addresses.
The port of the binding to remove.
The host header of the site binding to remove.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
A BindingInformation object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Adding and removing a site binding --------------
command:example.dev:code: New-WebBinding -Name "Default Web Site" -Port 1234 -IPAddress * -HostHeader "testsite" "Sleep 5 seconds before removing the binding"; Sleep 5 Get-WebBinding -Port 1234 -Name "Default Web Site" | Remove-WebBinding

dev:remarks.maml:para: Piping is used to remove the site binding created.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes an available IIS confguration backup.
Removes an IIS confguration backup created using the Backup-WebConfiguration cmdlet.
The name of the configuration backup to remove. The folder with this name is deleted from the $env:windir\system32\inetsrv\backup folder.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The name of the configuration backup to remove. The folder with this name is deleted from the $env:windir\system32\inetsrv\backup folder.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Adding and removing an IIS configuration backup --------------
command:example.dev:code: Backup-WebConfiguration MyNewBackup Get-WebConfigurationBackup MyNewBackup sleep 5 Remove-WebConfigurationBackup MyNewBackup

dev:remarks.maml:para: The example creates a configuration backup, lists the backup created, sleeps for 5 seconds, and then removes the backup.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes an IIS configuration location.
Removes an IIS configuration location.
The name of the configuration location to remove.
Specifies whether to also remove locations included within hierarchy of the specified location.
An IIS configuration path.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The name of the configuration location to remove.
Specifies whether to also remove locations included within hierarchy of the specified location.
An IIS configuration path.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Adding and removing a configuration location --------------
command:example.dev:code: Set-WebConfigurationProperty -PSPath "IIS:\" -Filter //windowsAuthentication -Location "Default Web Site/mypage.htm" -Name enabled -Value true Get-WebConfigurationLocation -Name "Default Web Site" -PSPath "IIS:\" "Sleep 5 seconds before removing the configuration location"; Sleep 5 Remove-WebConfigurationLocation -Name "Default Web Site/my*" Get-WebConfigurationLocation -Name "Default Web Site" -PSPath "IIS:\"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds and then removes a configuration location.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a lock on configuration settings.
Removes a lock on configuration settings.
Forces removal of the configuration lock.
Location of the configuration from which the lock is to be removed.
XPath filter expression.
An IIS configuration path.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Forces removal of the configuration lock.
Location of the configuration from which the lock is to be removed.
XPath filter expression.
An IIS configuration path.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Adding and removing configuration locks --------------
command:example.dev:code: Add-WebConfigurationLock -Type general -Filter //asp Remove-WebConfigurationLock -Filter //asp Add-WebConfigurationLock -Type inclusive -Filter //asp/@lcid Remove-WebConfigurationLock -Filter //asp/@lcid Add-WebConfigurationLock -Type exclusive -Filter //asp/@lcid

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example demonstrates how to add and remove configuration locks.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes an IIS configuration property.
Removes an IIS configuration property.
The name of the configuration property to remove.
The element at which the configuration property is removed.
The index at which the configuration property is removed.
The name of the configuration property at which the property is removed.
When the Force parameter is used, it causes the configuration property to be removed from a level higher in the configuration than a lock.

The location of the configuration property. Location tags are usually used for configuration settings that need to be more granular than per application or per virtual directory. Settings for particular files or directory are an example. Location tags are also used is if a particular section is locked. If so the configuration system has to use location tags in one of the parent configuration files.
Specifies the IIS configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration element.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The name of the configuration property to remove.
The element at which the configuration property is removed.
The index at which the configuration property is removed.
The name of the configuration property at which the property is removed.
When the Force parameter is used, it causes the configuration property to be removed from a level higher in the configuration than a lock.

The location of the configuration property. Location tags are usually used for configuration settings that need to be more granular than per application or per virtual directory. Settings for particular files or directory are an example. Location tags are also used is if a particular section is locked. If so the configuration system has to use location tags in one of the parent configuration files.
Specifies the IIS configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration element.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

maml:description.maml:para: Renames a configuration location.
Renames the specified configuration location with the new name provided.
The current name of the configuration location to rename.
The new name of the configuration location.
If included, specifies whether tags defined lower in the location hierarchy should also be renamed.
An IIS configuration path.

Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Renaming a configuration location --------------
command:example.dev:code: Rename-WebConfigurationLocation -Name 'Default Web Site/oldApp' -NewName 'Default Web Site/newApp' -PSPath IIS:\

dev:remarks.maml:para: Renames a configuration location on the Default Web Site from "oldApp" to "newApp".

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the value of an IIS configuration setting to the value specified in the command.
The Set-WebConfiguration cmdlet changes the value of an IIS configuration element. The element can be specified as a configuration section or an XPath query.
The value of the configuration setting to change.
If this parameter is specified, configuration metadata like encryption or locking settings can be changed.
When the Force parameter is used, it causes the configuration setting to be set at a level above a lock in the configuration.

The location of the configuration setting. Location tags are usually used for configuration settings that need to be more granular than per application or per virtual directory. Settings for particular files or directory are an example. Location tags are also used is if a particular section is locked. If so the configuration system has to use location tags in one of the parent configuration files.
Specifies the IIS configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration element.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
If this parameter is specified, configuration metadata like encryption or locking settings can be changed.
When the Force parameter is used, it causes the configuration setting to be set at a level above a lock in the configuration.

The location of the configuration setting. Location tags are usually used for configuration settings that need to be more granular than per application or per virtual directory. Settings for particular files or directory are an example. Location tags are also used is if a particular section is locked. If so the configuration system has to use location tags in one of the parent configuration files.
Specifies the IIS configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration element.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The value of the configuration setting to change.
If this parameter is specified, configuration metadata like encryption or locking settings can be changed.
When the Force parameter is used, it causes the configuration setting to be set at a level above a lock in the configuration.

The location of the configuration setting. Location tags are usually used for configuration settings that need to be more granular than per application or per virtual directory. Settings for particular files or directory are an example. Location tags are also used is if a particular section is locked. If so the configuration system has to use location tags in one of the parent configuration files.
Specifies the IIS configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration element.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1: Setting new Bindings on an existing Web site --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: The Set-WebConfiguration cmdlet is used to replace the existing bindings of the Web site named "DemoSite" with new bindings. The existing bindings are replaced.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the value of an IIS configuration setting to the value specified in the command.

The Set-WebConfigurationProperty cmdlet changes the value of an IIS configuration element. The element can be specified as a configuration section or a XPath query. Set-WebConfigurationProperty supports globbing.
The name of the configuration property to be changed.
The value of the configuration setting to be changed.
The element at which the configuration property is set.
The index at which the configuration property is set.
The name of the collection property for which the value is set.
The Force parameter is used cause the configuration property setting to be set at a level above a lock in the configuration.

The location of the configuration setting. Location tags are usually used for configuration settings that need to be more granular than per application or per virtual directory. Settings for particular files or directory are an example. Location tags are also used is if a particular section is locked. If so the configuration system has to use location tags in one of the parent configuration files.
Specifies the IIS configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration element.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The name of the configuration property to be changed.
The element at which the configuration property is set.
The index at which the configuration property is set.
The name of the collection property for which the value is set.
The Force parameter is used cause the configuration property setting to be set at a level above a lock in the configuration.

The location of the configuration setting. Location tags are usually used for configuration settings that need to be more granular than per application or per virtual directory. Settings for particular files or directory are an example. Location tags are also used is if a particular section is locked. If so the configuration system has to use location tags in one of the parent configuration files.
Specifies the IIS configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration element.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
The name of the configuration property to be changed.
The value of the configuration setting to be changed.
The element at which the configuration property is set.
The index at which the configuration property is set.
The name of the collection property for which the value is set.
The Force parameter is used cause the configuration property setting to be set at a level above a lock in the configuration.

The location of the configuration setting. Location tags are usually used for configuration settings that need to be more granular than per application or per virtual directory. Settings for particular files or directory are an example. Location tags are also used is if a particular section is locked. If so the configuration system has to use location tags in one of the parent configuration files.
Specifies the IIS configuration section or an XPath query that returns a configuration element.
Specifies the configuration path. This can be either an IIS configuration path (e.g. machine/webroot/apphost) or the IIS module path (e.g. 'IIS:\sites\Default Web Site').
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

providerHelp.Name: WebAdministration
providerHelp.Synopsis: Access to IIS configuration and run-time data

DetailedDescription.para: The Internet Information Services (IIS) module for Windows PowerShell lets you manage the configuration and run-time data of IIS. It implements a namespace hierarchy containing Application Pools, Web sites, Web applications and virtual directories. The IIS module implements one virtual drive named IIS. The root virtual folders are AppPools and Sites. Within the AppPools folder, run-time data, such as the currently running WorkerProcesses, AppDomains, and Requests can be found. The Sites folder contains Web site folders, as well as applications and virtual directories.

Task.Title: Displaying the contents of the IIS: drive

Introduction.para: This command uses the Get-Childitem cmdlet to display contents of the IIS root drive.

Remarks.para: If the current drive is IIS:\ you can omit the path.

Introduction.para: This example uses the Set-Location cmdlet to change the current location to the Sites folder.

Remarks.para: Use command-line completion by entering Set-Location Si<tab>.

Introduction.para: This example uses the Set-Location cmdlet to change the current location to the Sites\Default Web Site folder.

Remarks.para: Folder paths containing spaces must be enclosed in quotes.

Task.Title: Displaying the contents of the IIS drive

Introduction.para: This example uses the Get-Childitem cmdlet to display the existing Web sites in the Sites folder.

Remarks.para: If the current drive is IIS:\ you can omit the path.

Introduction.para: This command uses the Get-Childitem cmdlet to display items within the 'Default Web Site'.

Remarks.para: Folder paths containing spaces must be enclosed in quotes.

Introduction.para: This example demonstrates using the Get-ChildItem cmdlet with 'where' to constrain the output to applications only.

Remarks.para: You can do the same with 'Virtual Directory'.

Introduction.para: This command uses the Get-ChildItem cmdlet to display IIS Application Pools.

Remarks.para: If you are in the IIS: drive, you can omit the drive name.

Task.Title: Creating Web sites, application pools, Web applications and virtual directories

Introduction.para: The New-Item cmdlet is used to create a new Web site named DemoSite which listens on Port 8080.

Remarks.para: The folder specified for the site, C:\inetpub\DemoSite, must be created before executing the cmdlet.

Introduction.para: The New-Item cmdlet is used to create a new application pool.

Remarks.para: Use the Set-ItemProperty cmdlet to assign a site or an application to application pools.

Introduction.para: The New-Item cmdlet is used to create a new Web application under the 'Default Web Site'.

Remarks.para: The folder specified for the application, C:\inetpub\DemoApplication, must be created before executing the cmdlet.

Introduction.para: The New-Item cmdlet is used to create a new virtual directory under the Default Web Site.

Remarks.para: The folder specified for the virtual directory, C:\inetpub\DemoVirtualDirectory, must be created before executing the cmdlet.

Task.Title: Changing properties of a site, application pool, application, or virtual directory

Introduction.para: The Set-ItemProperty cmdlet is used to set the ApplicationPool property of an application.

Remarks.para: This examples uses the application named DemoApplication and the application pool named DemoPool created in the previous examples for the New-Item cmdlet.

Introduction.para: The Set-ItemProperty cmdlet is used to set the request limit for recycling the application pool to 100000.

Remarks.para: This examples uses the application named DemoApplication created in the previous examples for the New-Item cmdlet.

Introduction.para: The Set-ItemProperty cmdlet is used to change the physical path of a virtual directory.

Remarks.para: This examples uses the virtual directory named DemoVirtualDirectory created in the previous examples for the New-Item cmdlet.

Introduction.para: The Set-ItemProperty cmdlet is used to change the binding of a site.

Remarks.para: This examples uses the site named DemoSite created in the previous examples for the New-Item cmdlet.

Introduction.para: The New-ItemProperty cmdlet is used to add a new binding to an existing Web site.

Remarks.para: This examples uses the site named DemoSite created in the previous examples for the New-Item cmdlet.

Introduction.para: The Clear-ItemProperty cmdlet is used to remove all bindings from an existing Web site

Remarks.para: This examples uses the site named DemoSite created in the previous examples for the New-Item cmdlet.

Introduction.para: The Set-ItemProperty cmdlet is used to replace existing bindings with a set of new bindings. An array of hash tables is used to achieve this.

Remarks.para: This examples uses the site named DemoSite created in the previous examples for the New-Item cmdlet.

Introduction.para: The Remove-ItemProperty cmdlet is used to remove an existing binding from the bindings collection.

Remarks.para: This examples uses the site named DemoSite created in the previous examples for the New-Item cmdlet.

Introduction.para: The Rename-Item cmdlet is used to rename an existing IIS configuration object.

Remarks.para: This examples uses the site named DemoSite created in the previous examples for the New-Item cmdlet.

DynamicParameter.Name: PhysicalPath
DynamicParameter.Description: Specifies the file system path for a Web site or application.

DynamicParameter.Name: Bindings
DynamicParameter.Description: Specifies the bindings for a site.

DynamicParameter.Name: Type
DynamicParameter.Description: Specifies the type of a new IIS item.
